chunks.chunk_text: Hello, this is 6 Minute English from BBC Learning English. I'm Neil.And I'm Beth.There are some well-known English expressions that make a link between seeing and eating.

But seeing isn't the only sense involved in tasting food. In fact, it may not even be the most important. First you see your favourite bacon sandwich, then comes its delicious smell, quickly followed by the crunchy feel and salty taste as you take a bite.
But first I have a question for you, Beth.The idea that sounds influence taste might seem strange, but the food processing companies that produce some of our most familiar food and drinks

have long known that sound equals sales.In the UK, for example, the chocolate company Cadbury hired the London Contemporary Orchestra to perform classical music tunes symbolising each flavour of their dairy milk chocolates.So which background sound did whisky makers singletons use to advertise their Scotch whisky?

I will guess they used some smooth jazz music.OK, Beth, I'll reveal the answer later in the programme.Charles Spence is Professor of Experimental Psychology at Oxford University.After years studying how our brains process information, he believes sound plays a much bigger role in how we taste our food than we think, something he explained to Mike Johnson, presenter of BBC World Service programme The Food Chain.

In general, how big a contribution do you think these sounds and sound generally actually makes to how we perceive food compared to the more obvious senses, of course, of sight and smell?So I think it's much more important than we realise.And that can start from before we've put anything into our mouth.It can be the sound of the sizzle of the steak on the hot plate.It can be the gurgle and the sizzle and the steam of the coffee machine.Those are all cues that help set expectations about what we're about to taste.
Professor Spence uses onomatopoeia to describe some sounds.
But it's not just psychologists.The food industry has also discovered

music design company mood media for BBC World Service programme The Food Chain.Choosing the right dining room music not only makes food taste better, it puts people in a good mood, something which might lead

That was the wrong answer, I'm afraid, Beth.In fact, singletons use the sound of birds tweeting to sell their whiskey.Probably a better idea than using bagpipes.OK, let's recap the vocabulary we've learned from this programme on sonic seasoning, starting with the English saying you eat with your eyes first, an idiom meaning that when food is visually appealing, it's more appetising.
